scenes.plot_segment: Dr. Richard Webber narrates a recap of the intense pressures and expectations facing surgical interns at Seattle Grace Hospital, warning that residency will test their limits and not everyone will succeed. Scenes highlight Dr. Meredith Grey’s complicated dynamic with Dr. Derek Shepherd, referencing their one-night stand and Meredith’s insistence on maintaining professional boundaries since Derek is her attending. The montage introduces Dr. Miranda Bailey assigning the new interns—Meredith, Cristina Yang, Izzie Stevens, George O’Malley, and Alex Karev—their initial duties and making it clear they are at the bottom of the hospital hierarchy. The interns gossip about Meredith’s background as the daughter of renowned surgeon Ellis Grey, and Meredith’s search for roommates is mentioned, with Cristina, Izzie, and George expressing interest in moving in. The recap also touches on Meredith’s strained relationship with her mother, Ellis, who is suffering from Alzheimer’s and does not recognize her. The sequence ends with reminders of the personal and professional challenges the interns face as they begin their surgical careers.

Meredith Grey narrates about the boundaries people draw in life and at work, emphasizing the need to keep a professional distance from colleagues to avoid complications. As her voice-over continues, Meredith interviews potential roommates at her house, making it clear she is selective about who she lets move in. She rejects one candidate for being too old. Izzie Stevens tries to persuade Meredith to let her move in, offering baked goods and promising to be a considerate roommate, but Meredith insists she only wants strangers as housemates. Cristina Yang also expresses interest in moving in, but Meredith remains hesitant, determined to keep her personal and professional lives separate.

In the hospital hallway, Dr. Miranda Bailey gathers the new surgical interns—Meredith Grey, Cristina Yang, Izzie Stevens, and George O’Malley—and assigns their first tasks: George is put in charge of running the code team, Meredith is given the trauma pager, Cristina is responsible for delivering lab results, and Izzie is assigned to sutures. Izzie attempts to win Bailey’s favor by offering her a homemade mocha latte, but Bailey firmly rejects the gesture and reminds all the interns that their primary job is to keep their resident happy by handling the grunt work. She makes it clear that none of them will be allowed near an operating room until she is satisfied with their performance, establishing her authority and the hierarchy they must respect.

Dr. Meredith Grey and Dr. Derek Shepherd share an awkward early morning conversation outside Seattle Grace Hospital. Derek, trying to break the tension, brings up Seattle’s ferry boats, expressing his fondness for them, while Meredith, originally from New York, admits she never expected to like Seattle or its ferries. The conversation quickly turns to their one-night stand; Meredith firmly tells Derek that they cannot pursue anything further because he is her attending and she is his intern. Derek playfully challenges her boundaries, but Meredith insists on drawing a clear professional line between them. Their banter becomes lighthearted as Derek jokes about whether the boundary is imaginary or if Meredith needs to physically draw it with a marker, highlighting the unresolved tension and humor in their dynamic.

In the emergency department, Dr. Alex Karev and Dr. Cristina Yang respond to the arrival of a 25-year-old woman named Allison, who has been brought in as a trauma case after surviving a violent rape attempt. Dr. Miranda Bailey oversees as the interns assess Allison’s injuries and discuss her case. Meredith Grey, assigned to the trauma pager, joins them and examines the evidence, discovering a severed penis in a specimen jar. The team learns that Allison fought back against her attacker, biting off his penis during the assault. The rape kit comes back negative, confirming that Allison successfully defended herself. The interns react with shock and a mix of admiration for Allison’s courage, while Dr. Bailey reminds them to focus on their responsibilities and maintain the chain of custody for the evidence until the police arrive.

Dr. Preston Burke and Dr. Derek Shepherd discuss Allison’s critical condition, acknowledging that her recovery will be long and uncertain if she survives her injuries. As they review her chart, Burke questions why Shepherd chose to move to Seattle, prompting Derek to reveal that Chief Richard Webber personally recruited him to join the hospital. Their exchange is brief and tense, with Burke clearly unsettled by Derek’s presence and the chief’s decision, before Burke abruptly ends the conversation and walks away.

Dr. Miranda Bailey gathers the interns and assigns their responsibilities for the day: George O’Malley is put in charge of the code team, Meredith Grey takes the trauma pager, Cristina Yang is tasked with delivering lab results, and Izzie Stevens is assigned to sutures. Cristina, frustrated that her advanced degrees have led to running errands, vents her annoyance. Bailey pairs Alex Karev with Cristina, instructing him to shadow her for the day. Cristina and Alex immediately clash, exchanging sarcastic remarks and making it clear they dislike each other, but begrudgingly agree to work together to get through their tasks.

George O’Malley, nervously introduced as “Dr. O’Malley,” prepares to lead the code team on a 57-year-old male patient in cardiac arrest, under the watchful eye of Dr. Miranda Bailey and several nurses. As George tries to recall the correct procedures, Bailey gives him terse instructions, testing his ability to handle the pressure. Meanwhile, Izzie Stevens attempts to communicate with Mrs. Liu, a patient who speaks only Chinese. Izzie asks Cristina Yang for help, but Cristina explains she is Korean and cannot translate. Frustrated, Izzie searches the busy hallway for anyone who speaks Chinese, determined to find a way to help Mrs. Liu despite the language barrier.

Meredith Grey brings the severed penis, identified as belonging to Allison’s attacker, to a hospital staff member for evidence processing. She is informed that, due to strict chain of custody protocols, she must personally retain possession of the specimen until the police arrive to collect it. Uncertain and visibly uncomfortable about carrying such a sensitive item, Meredith nonetheless accepts responsibility and keeps the specimen with her, following hospital procedure.

Dr. Bailey informs her patient, Mrs. Liu, through a translator that she has a rare but minor disorder and can be discharged without surgery. Mrs. Liu is visibly relieved, having feared her condition was life-threatening. Meanwhile, in the intern locker room, Izzie, Cristina, and George discuss Meredith’s responsibility for maintaining the chain of custody for the severed penis from Allison’s rape case, which she is keeping in a cooler until the police arrive. The interns joke nervously about the bizarre task, but the mood shifts when Izzie confides that Allison was wearing the same shoes as her, making the case feel disturbingly personal. Izzie admits she feels unsettled and exhausted, and the group grows quiet, reflecting on the emotional toll of their first day.

Cristina Yang and Meredith Grey meet in a quiet corridor, discussing their secret coping ritual—sneaking away to watch surgeries from the gallery when the stress of intern life becomes overwhelming. Cristina calls their habit “sick and twisted,” but both admit it helps them survive the relentless pressure at Seattle Grace. Cristina debates whether they should keep doing it, but ultimately decides she needs the escape and invites Meredith to join her. As they head toward the gallery, George O’Malley rushes by, responding to a code blue, leaving the two women to their clandestine break.

Meredith Grey enters the pediatric ward and notices a baby with a heart murmur who is turning blue, concerned that no tests have been ordered. She questions the pediatric attending, who dismisses her concerns and insists the murmur is benign, reminding Meredith that the baby is not her patient and telling her to leave. Meredith persists, pressing the attending about the baby's symptoms, but the attending becomes defensive and orders her out of the room, refusing to take further action.

Izzie Stevens is approached by a hospital staff member who needs help communicating with Mrs. Liu, a patient who only speaks Chinese. Izzie, assuming Cristina Yang might be able to help, asks her to translate, but Cristina clarifies that she is Korean and does not speak Chinese. Unable to find a translator, Izzie and Cristina struggle to communicate with Mrs. Liu, leaving the language barrier unresolved and complicating Mrs. Liu’s care.

Dr. Preston Burke confronts Chief Richard Webber in his office, questioning why Dr. Derek Shepherd was recruited to Seattle Grace. Burke, feeling threatened about his own chances of becoming chief of surgery, presses Richard for answers. Richard explains that Derek is a former student and insists there is no hidden agenda. Burke expresses frustration, worried that his position is at risk with Derek’s arrival. Richard challenges Burke, criticizing him for only meeting expectations rather than exceeding them, and tells him that if he wants to be chief, he needs to prove he deserves it rather than expecting it to be handed to him.

Cristina Yang and Alex Karev race to deliver lab results as quickly as possible, agreeing to split the list of patients and keep their interactions strictly professional, avoiding emotional involvement. In a nearby exam room, Dr. Izzie Stevens and Dr. George O’Malley inform Mrs. Liu, a Chinese-speaking patient, that her test results are clear—she does not need an amputation, her kidneys are healthy, and she is free to go home. Izzie reassures Mrs. Liu, using gestures and simple words to overcome the language barrier, while George offers a supportive smile, and Mrs. Liu expresses her relief and gratitude before leaving.

Meredith, Izzie, and George move through the hospital, discharging patients and offering congratulations as they complete their rounds. Their conversation turns lighthearted as Izzie teases George about his taste in music, prompting a brief debate about favorite bands. In another part of the hospital, George responds to a code but arrives too late to save the patient; Dr. Bailey calls the time of death, and George quietly processes the emotional weight before returning to his duties.

Dr. Miranda Bailey instructs a nurse to call every hospital in the county, anticipating that Allison’s attacker will seek emergency care for his injuries. Meredith Grey learns from another staff member that Allison, the rape victim, has no family in Seattle to support her. The staff express concern and sympathy for Allison’s isolation, highlighting the emotional toll the case is taking on everyone involved.

Meredith, visibly troubled after handling the rape case evidence, excuses herself from the group, saying she has something she needs to take care of. She approaches Dr. Preston Burke and tells him she noticed a baby in the pediatric ward with a possible heart murmur. Burke, adhering strictly to hospital protocol, refuses to examine the baby without a formal consult from Pediatrics, reminding Meredith that he cannot intervene without the proper request from the pediatric team. Meredith is frustrated by his response but is left with no choice but to follow the chain of command.

Izzie Stevens is recognized by a patient who saw her photo in a modeling magazine, prompting some teasing from Alex Karev. After finishing the patient’s sutures and directing them to see the nurse, Izzie moves on to Mrs. Liu, a Chinese-speaking patient who is hesitant to let Izzie examine her injured arm. Struggling with the language barrier and unable to get help from Cristina Yang, who doesn’t speak Chinese, Izzie gently reassures Mrs. Liu and eventually gains her trust, convincing her to allow the examination.

Izzie and George find a quiet spot away from the chaos of the hospital to decompress after a grueling shift. Izzie vents about her overwhelming day and awkwardly admits to George that she kissed Dr. Eric in the elevator, not Derek Shepherd. They share a laugh about the absurdity of their experiences, including Meredith having to carry the severed penis for the police and Allison, the rape victim, wearing the same shoes as Meredith. Both reflect on how surreal and unsettling their new lives as surgical interns have become, finding comfort in confiding in each other amidst the strangeness.

Security responds as paramedics wheel in a new patient under heavy guard—the man identified as Allison’s attacker, his injuries severe from the assault. Dr. Miranda Bailey quickly assesses the situation while Meredith Grey is instructed to contact Chief Webber and inform him that the rapist has been apprehended and brought to Seattle Grace. The surgical team prepares for emergency treatment, aware of the gravity of the case and the heightened tension among staff.

Dr. Miranda Bailey and the surgical team examine the rapist’s injuries, concluding that his penis cannot be reattached due to the extent of the damage. Dr. Bailey informs the team that the patient will be permanently incontinent and impotent. Dr. Richard Webber, the chief of surgery, is notified that the rapist has arrived at Seattle Grace for treatment. Meanwhile, Dr. Preston Burke confronts Chief Webber about his future at the hospital, expressing frustration over being overlooked for advancement. Webber criticizes Burke for only meeting expectations instead of exceeding them, challenging him to prove he deserves the position of chief.

Izzie Stevens struggles to communicate with Mrs. Liu, a Chinese-speaking patient who is hesitant to enter the hospital because she is undocumented. Unable to bridge the language barrier or reassure her, Izzie reluctantly sends Mrs. Liu away for the time being. Meanwhile, Meredith Grey, Cristina Yang, George O’Malley, Izzie, and Alex Karev gather in a hallway, venting their frustrations about the menial tasks assigned to them and their lack of real surgical experience. Meredith complains about having to store the severed penis from Allison’s case overnight due to police delays, feeling both disturbed and burdened by the responsibility. Alex tries to lighten the mood with a crude joke, but the group remains discouraged, overwhelmed by the emotional and physical demands of their first days as interns.

Meredith enters the nursery and discreetly approaches the parents of the baby she suspects has a heart murmur, expressing her concern and urging them to ask for further evaluation. The pediatrician, Dr. Knox, notices Meredith’s interference and confronts her, frustrated that a surgical intern is overstepping into pediatrics. As tensions rise, Dr. Preston Burke arrives, asserting his authority as an attending surgeon. He listens to the baby’s heart, confirms Meredith’s suspicion of a possible congenital defect, and orders an echocardiogram and additional tests. Dr. Burke reassures the anxious parents, explains the next steps, and takes over the case, while sternly warning Meredith not to undermine another physician’s care in the future.

Outside the hospital, Dr. Izzie Stevens, accompanied by Dr. George O’Malley and Dr. Meredith Grey, finds Mrs. Liu, a Chinese-speaking patient who is afraid to enter the hospital because she is undocumented. Mrs. Liu, anxious about being reported to immigration authorities, hesitates to accept care. Izzie reassures her that they will not report her and offers to treat her wound outside. With George and Meredith’s help, Izzie carefully cleans and stitches Mrs. Liu’s injury, explaining each step in simple terms to ease her fear. Meredith gives Mrs. Liu a card with contact information and instructions to return in five days for a follow-up. Grateful, Mrs. Liu thanks the interns, calling Izzie a good doctor and person before leaving. The three interns share a quiet moment, reflecting on the challenges their patients face and the small ways they can help.

Cristina Yang approaches Dr. Preston Burke and asks if he thinks she comes across as overly confident. Burke, maintaining his authoritative demeanor, tells Cristina she has thirty seconds to speak candidly. Taking the opportunity, Cristina bluntly tells Burke that he is cocky, arrogant, bossy, pushy, and has a God complex, listing each trait without hesitation. She continues her forthright critique until Burke interrupts her, signaling the end of her allotted time.

George O’Malley confides in Izzie Stevens about his distress after losing five patients while running the code team, feeling responsible and calling himself the "angel of death." Izzie reassures George, explaining that most code patients are beyond saving before they even arrive and that he shouldn’t blame himself for outcomes he can’t control. George admits he wishes someone had told him this earlier, and Izzie offers comfort, reminding him that being an intern is hard and that he’s not alone in feeling overwhelmed.

Meredith Grey and George O’Malley sit together, discussing the upcoming heart surgery for the baby Meredith flagged earlier. Meredith confides that she was convinced she was right about the diagnosis, but admits she’s terrified she might have been wrong. George reassures her, saying that as interns, they’re always scared and rarely certain, but that fear is part of the job. They both acknowledge feeling overwhelmed by the responsibility and pressure of being new surgical interns, bonding over their shared anxiety and uncertainty.

George O’Malley sits quietly at Allison’s bedside as she remains unconscious after her assault, reflecting on his own family and how he would want his four sisters by his side if he were in a coma. Meredith Grey joins him, and they share a moment of empathy for Allison’s isolation, noting that she has no family in Seattle. George expresses his hope that Allison knows someone cares, even if she can’t hear him. Meredith, thinking of her own complicated relationship with her mother, Ellis Grey, wonders aloud how her mother would react in a similar situation. The conversation shifts as Meredith and George discuss the emotional toll of their work, with George admitting how hard it is to witness so much suffering. Meredith glances through the nursery window at a newborn baby, reflecting on the stark contrast between the innocence of new life and the trauma Allison has endured. The two interns sit in silence, united by the weight of their responsibilities and the vulnerability of their patients.

In the OR, Dr. Burke and the surgical team operate on Allison, the rape victim, after her intracranial pressure spikes dangerously. Meredith, Cristina, and Alex assist, anxiously watching as Burke removes a section of Allison’s skull to relieve the swelling. After the surgery, Dr. Burke updates Meredith and the other interns: Allison’s skull flap was left off due to severe brain swelling, and her condition remains critical. Burke explains that Allison’s prognosis is uncertain—she may not survive unless she regains consciousness soon. The interns process the gravity of the situation, shaken by the fragility of their patient’s life and the limits of what surgery can accomplish.

Dr. Preston Burke is approached by Dr. Derek Shepherd, who suggests they get a drink together, but Burke declines. As they talk, both men reveal that Chief Richard Webber has privately promised each of them the position of chief of surgery. They acknowledge that they are now direct competitors for the job, but agree that while they are rivals, they do not have to be enemies.

Meredith, visibly uneasy, receives instructions from a senior nurse on how to properly sign the chain of custody paperwork for the severed penis, which is being held as evidence in the rape case. Meredith hesitates, admitting her discomfort because she used to care for the patient as a child and once changed his diapers. Despite her unease, she completes the necessary documentation, and the evidence is formally handed over to the police officer waiting nearby.

In the operating room, Dr. Preston Burke prepares for surgery on the infant with a congenital heart defect. He instructs Meredith Grey to scrub in, acknowledging her initiative in catching the diagnosis, and tells her she can assist by holding the clamp during the procedure. Meredith, both nervous and excited, joins Burke and the surgical team as they get ready to operate, aware that this is a rare opportunity for an intern.

Dr. Miranda Bailey informs the rapist, now a patient in the hospital, that his bleeding has been controlled and that his severed penis will be handed over to the police as evidence. She bluntly tells him that due to the injury, he will be incontinent and impotent for the rest of his life. In a nearby bed, Dr. Izzie Stevens reassures another patient that their tumor is benign and they are cleared to go home, offering a moment of relief amid the tense atmosphere.

Meredith narrates about boundaries and the lines people draw, reflecting on how they can keep others out but also trap oneself inside. In the kitchen of her house, Meredith tells George and Izzie that they can move in with her, finally agreeing after much hesitation. George and Izzie are thrilled and celebrate, while Cristina teases Meredith that the babies she saw in the hospital softened her up. Meredith jokingly blames the babies for her decision. As the friends laugh together, Meredith’s narration continues, suggesting that life is less about drawing lines and more about having the courage to cross them, even if it means risking vulnerability and connection.

Meredith Grey and Derek Shepherd cross paths in the hospital hallway. Derek tries to engage Meredith in conversation by mentioning Seattle’s ferry boats, but Meredith keeps her distance, reminding him that they can’t be involved because he is her attending and she is his intern. She pointedly chooses to take the stairs instead of the elevator, referencing their lack of self-control and reinforcing her boundaries. As Meredith walks away, her internal narration reflects on the necessity and risks of crossing boundaries, suggesting that sometimes taking chances can lead to extraordinary outcomes.
